conclusion: The thin parallel beam enters the flat surface at point C, which is located a distance OC = (√3/3) R above the centre O.
Join C to the centre of curvature of the semicylinder (the midpoint of the circular arc), call this point P. The radius PC equals R and is normal to the curved surface at P.
The incident beam travels in air along the axis AO and reaches the plane surface at C normally (angle = 0°); it therefore enters the material of the semicylinder without deviation.
After entering, the ray travels straight to the curved surface and meets it at P.
At P the radius PC makes an angle θ with the ray equal to the angle between PC and the horizontal axis. From the right-triangle OPC, tan θ = OC/OP = (√3/3 R)/R = √3/3, so θ = 30°.
For the beam just to disappear from the right-hand side, the refracted angle at the curved surface must reach the critical value for total internal reflection: r = 90°.
Hence Snell’s law at P gives n sin i = 1 · sin 90° = 1, where i = θ = 30° is the angle inside the material.
The required refractive index of the semicylindrical transparent material for the given monochromatic light is n = 2.
